content.question: Let f be a twice-differentiable function on the open interval (a,b). If f'(x) > 0 on (a,b) and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>″</mo> </msup> <mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3B6F@</annotation> </semantics> </math> on (a,b), which of the following could be the graph of f?

choices.label: The graph is a line segment that starts at a point slightly above a and moves to a higher point above b.
The graph is a curve that starts at a point slightly above a, begins moving gradually up and to the right, continues moving more steeply up and to the right, and ends at a point above b.
The graph is a curve that starts at a point slightly above a, begins moving steeply up and to the right, and gradually becomes more level, ending at a point above b.
The graph is a curve that starts at a point above a, begins moving steeply down and to the right, and gradually becomes more level, ending at a point slightly above b.
The graph is a curve that starts at a point above a, begins moving gradually down and to the right, continues moving more steeply down and to the right, and ends at a point slightly above b.

content.answer: The graph is a curve that starts at a point slightly above a, begins moving steeply up and to the right, and gradually becomes more level, ending at a point above b.

topic.text: 5.8: Sketching Graphs of Functions and Their Derivatives

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
